key_behaviors: Uses multiple AI tools (ChatGPT, Claude, Microsoft Copilot, Perplexity) multiple times per day
Leverages AI for copy‑editing emails and personal writing
Creates study guides, flashcards, and asks AI to act as a coach or teacher
Uses AI for research tasks and quick information gathering
Attempts to use AI for complex work‑related tasks (e.g., competitive analysis) but abandons when it fails
Envisions AI helping with transcription, drafting surveys, and research methodology
pain_points: AI cannot perform in‑depth competitive analysis from a user‑research perspective
Difficulty crafting prompts that yield useful results leads to frustration
Frequent failure on complex tasks causes the participant to stop using AI for those tasks
Lack of trust in AI connecting to personal systems (calendar, email, etc.)
Overall moderate trust (rating 3) indicates uncertainty about AI reliability
trust_factors: Trust in AI for surface‑level copy editing and generating concise text
Distrust of AI handling personal data or system integrations without explicit control
desires: An AI that acts as a constant teacher or intern for work tasks
AI assistance that speeds up copy editing, transcription, and first‑draft creation of surveys and research methods
Tighter integration with work tools **only if** the user retains full control
AI that can conduct rapid user‑testing interviews, reducing preparation time and moderator fatigue
A reliable AI partner for complex analytical work that currently fails (e.g., competitive analysis)

verbatim_quotes.quote: Mostly copy editing, a lot of research, and then a lot of study guides, like asking it, "What is this? What is that? How can I do this?"

For my copy editing work, it's making my emails sound clearer and more concise. It's also helping with rewriting things in my personal life, just general copy editing. It's like having a copy editor on my phone.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Value of AI for copy editing

verbatim_quotes.quote: So it's like study guides for learning AI. ... create a study guide, create flashcards, etcetera.

I was trying to use Perplexity to perform a competitive analysis from a user research perspective, but either I wasn't getting my prompt right or it just couldn't do it. I became frustrated, so I stopped trying.
It was very common, so I stopped using AI tools, like commercial LLMs, for competitive analysis.
On average, how much do you trust the results or suggestions you get from AI tools? 3 - Moderate trust
I guess maybe, like, I don't know, a constant teacher or like an intern for work. Something that helps me more in my work life instead of my personal life.
Because it helped me work faster and be more efficient.
I mean copy editing, transcribing transcripts, transcribing notes, and creating first drafts of things like surveys or research methodology approaches, and so forth.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Specific work tasks for AI support

verbatim_quotes.quote: I don't trust it to do that. That's the one thing in my life I want control over.

I like that it asked unique follow‑up questions based on the answers I gave to the previous questions, but it still followed the overall format of the study and the research questions we have for this class project.
It would take less time to prepare everything, but this would also help me test faster, at least for the initial prototypes that we want to test at work. It would provide quick wins.
verbatim_quotes.topic: Value of AI for rapid testing

verbatim_quotes.quote: Instead of taking three weeks to handle all the logistics and recruiting, we could focus on recruiting and then use this for the testing, so our researcher wouldn't be tired from moderating all these tests.

unique_insights: The participant, a UX strategist, sees AI not just as a personal productivity tool but as a potential "constant teacher/intern" that could dramatically accelerate research workflows—especially rapid prototype testing and interview moderation—yet remains wary of granting AI deep integration with personal systems. This blend of high expectations for work‑focused assistance and strong control preferences is a nuanced stance that highlights the need for granular permission models and transparent, task‑specific competence guarantees.
